body: @mdeuser, only bashauto is exempt from `sdk install` as it does not require a connection the the API host. The auto-complete script is generated by Cobra. Only those `property get` commands that do not require the API host are exempt.
Duplicate of #350.
@psuter, will changes to the CLI be required for these changes?
No. The idea is to signal the binary-ness, but not require clients to know what they're sending. In #1357 I'll detect the only non-obvious case (JS actions) at creation time.
(When we, eventually, move to API v2, we will also be able to use the `Content-type` header to determine the nature of actions being created. The CLI will need support for that then.)
Possible duplicate of #1353 ?
Partly agree, though #1353 seems to be more geared towards the internals? I think this is just a bug in the response handling in the CLI.

Which invoker runtime were you using when this issue was encountered?

I'm pretty sure the CLI encountered a 502 HTTP response code (similar to #1353).  Would you please run the same command with the `-d` option and include the CLI output.
Yes the CLI encountered a 502. That's what the controller returns for a blocking invocation that fails with an `application developer error`. It's specified like that in swagger.

In addition to the `-d` CLI dump, would you also include the action code you used when encountering this issue.  If the code is not nodejs based and is not using a rejected Promise to return error results, then this is a separate issue.

PG1 #683 is blueish.
Yes auto-create still on for the moment. You want it completely off for this PR?
No. Just confirming.

I did an experiment with exposing the CLI through Homebrew recently.
https://github.com/jthomas/homebrew-tools/blob/master/wsk.rb

It worked perfectly although this file now fails the checksum test because the Go CLI has been updated. 

If we could work out how to trigger building this file when the Go CLI changes, you can just drop that repo in the OpenWhisk org and it'll work.

The revised code/implementation is much cleaner and clearer - nicely done. I pushed a few more updates to the branch as I reviewed the code. I polished some of the tests to remove unnecessary cruft and suggest doing the remaining tests in a similar way.

One last outstanding item is making sure old style sequence execs are still executable (a test is missing for this case) - @ioana-blue is aware and will amend the pr.
Deferring to @mdeuser.

Given that docker-compose is OS independent I've automated it with Travis to make it easy to maintain. 

Comparing to a previous build this one adds about 94 seconds out of which 30 are used currently to wait for the invoker to set up a Kafka topic. 

The build reuses the docker containers built by the existing Travis build and that's why it's pretty fast, but it could also be invoked independently, in which case it builds the containers. When executed independently the total time is approx 15 minutes ( b/c it only builds distDocker )

We could think of invoking it separately maybe by using OpenWhisk itself and write a simple function to be executed on every Git commit :). I don't know otherwise if we could invoke multiple Travis builds on each commit. Another idea is that Travis builds the containers and uploads them to a place like Docker Hub from which another build pulls the latest versions of the containers and runs some tests - this would work well for a performance tests suite.

For the moment I tried doing the simplest thing that works.
There was another request for this from an attendee at the Serverless NYC meetup last night.
I'd say the other work is lower priority but I'd still aim to get this done by end October.
No PG as this only concerns the TravisCI pipeline.

I discussed the latest revision with Nick. There is still a race between delete and get. To address it the plan is to replicate the logic for update so that handling delete is the same (locks the transaction to invalidate and bypass cache on get).
Thanks for doing my job and reproducing the error @mdeuser :+1:
@csantanapr please review and merge.

LGTM.
1. I agree that log checking is better than what we had before and topic creation should fail if it's not really up.
2. However, we should turn off auto-create in the next Kafka PR so that we can be sure it's really doing what we expect.  Test topic creation could be moved to the testing task or by rewriting the unit test.

@csantanapr, ready for review.
@paulcastro, is Swift 3 the only version that we support?
We support Swift 2 and 3.  Swift 2 is going to be deprecated in the near future.
With your updates, users will no longer be able to access Swift 2. Perhaps adding a `swift:2` tag as well would be ideal since we are deprecating it instead of removing the version.
True.  They can still set --kind swift though, where "swift" maps to swift 2.
Ah, I see now. Looks good.

CLI "--lib" support may end up part of #1403 and could be reused here.

Since the zip file uploads for the other runtimes is centered around zip, I will change from tgz to zip so the formats are consistent (if we're only going to support one now it should be the same one).
Minor tweaks made.   Additional deferred item is the Identity vs Subject issue which we can do after the consul removal step (this is to avoid additional semantic change in case we need to rollback).

Fixes #1409

Explicitly set docker API version can fix this issue: 
`echo docker_api_version=1.21 >> /etc/environment`
That would be awesome.

I've heard this question asked by several members of the community when they hear about OpenWhisk. Sounds like a good way to run the underlying services across a fabric of resources in what's becoming the industry standard way to orchestrate containers of services.

Exactly my thoughts. We move all our current applications to OpenShift (which is Kubernetes-based). For future developments it would be desirable to have a Serverless framework like OpenWhisk available. This would require OpenWhisk to run all its core components in containers (you cannot install anything on the underlying hosts) and then have access to the Kubernetes API to schedule additional containers as needed.

I researched Serverless frameworks for Kubernetes but there is nothing that looks like it has enough features and long-term support. Meanwhile DC/OS offers the Gestalt framework as an emerging, first-class plugin for Serverless computing.

"This would require OpenWhisk to run all its core components in containers (you cannot install anything on the underlying hosts) and then have access to the Kubernetes API to schedule additional containers as needed." - Exactly, this is going to be a shift in the current design and we are definitely investigating it. We have initially looked at container orchestrators last year, but the milliseconds response time which we needed wasn't being satisfied at the time, and we are revisiting them again. 

As and when we plan it, it will roll out as part of the Multi-cloud Whisk umbrella
https://developer.ibm.com/openwhisk/2016/08/08/multicloud-openwhisk-build-a-distributed-openwhisk-deployment-on-openstack
All done.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/1cf32889678c524f6cb0f8de1c132661517c2374.

The way we adjust transaction id is by modifying the active transid of the container itself.  We should continue doing this rather than doing a specific override for one of the methods.   Line 278 of ContainerPool shows how this is done (binding a transsaction id to a container).
Will be PG2 437

We are now fully on docker 1.12 and I'll start looking into this again.  The main issue is to note that there may need to be a retry for the config file (or a particular field) to appear as `docker run` is not instant and docker makes no promise about how started a container is (or daemon state) when the call returns.

@dubeejw the Swift 3 Whisk Object fails on Travis, but succeeds in all PG and local builds.  I'll disable the test and open issue #1416  to investigate why it is only failing on Travis.  I rebased and included a bug fix to address issue #1400.

Sorry for the delay. Yes. There are multiple "_". Please close is as duplicated. Thanks.
Thanks for the clarification.

Estimated steps for this feature:
- [x] Investigate how docker namespaces behave if the kernel does not support it (should gracefully ignore and continue). We need this to support old kernels in travis and vagrant.
- [x] Update ansible playbooks with `--userns=host` for regular containers (modulo step 1 works)
- [x] Update docker daemon settings with `--userns-remap=default` 
- [x] Make sure invoker runs actions in namespaced containers
- [x] Review tests & doc
Also would be good to check if there the 0.12 need to be refresh, which is not critical since it's now deprecated. it would depend on what type of changes is contains (i.e. security, etc..)
How do we specify in the cli that .zip it's only supported for nodejs kind?
Will `wsk action create -h` and `wsk action update -h` specify this?
Also I don't see a test for when user uses .zip and not nodejs `wsk create action --kind swift foo.zip`

That's should error if user pass .zip and not nodejs
It should error stating that at the moment .zip are only supported with nodejs kinds
